text: When I feel overstimulated, I notice what triggered it and I step away before it becomes overwhelming.
I recognize when my mind processes more information than others and I protect my energy accordingly.
When unexpected shifts disrupt my internal structure, I pause and create a clear route to follow.
I let sensory triggers or social pressure overwhelm me without recognizing the early signs of shutdown.
I notice when my reactions are amplified signals versus when they're true overreactions.
When I sense tension rising, I pause and breathe to slow my nervous system before it peaks.
I recognize what drains me versus what fuels me, and I make choices based on this knowledge.
I let too many inputs drain my cognitive resources without protecting my mental energy.
When I notice details intensely, I see it as a strength and use it instead of fighting it.
I recognize when my pattern-based thinking is disrupted and I create predictability to reduce stress.
When I feel my nervous system processing more data, I ground myself through physical anchors or breathing.
I let social situations drain me without preparing my mind or environment ahead of time.
I notice when my deep focus abilities are available versus when they're collapsed by too many demands.
When I recognize my sensory triggers, I create environments that support my brain instead of fighting it.
I see when my emotional spikes come from amplified signals and I guide them before they explode.
I let sudden changes or pattern breaks increase stress without creating mental maps to reduce chaos.
When I feel overloaded, I place my feet firmly and breathe slowly to calm my internal world.
I recognize when my strong interests are engines that recharge me versus distractions to fight.
When I notice my mind works in patterns, I use this system instead of fighting against it.
I let my unique operating system feel like a fault instead of understanding how to use it strategically.
